8 jan 2019 4:57 pm est:
0:01 1st light-bulb is just thin-wire having electrical-current,which make
that thin-wire hot and glowing.that is called bare-filament/bare-wire electric-lamp,
1st made by humphry-davy year 1800.
0:12 thomas-alva-edison insert that bare-wire-electric-lamp inside a glass-bulb,to keep
away oxygen from that bare-wire because oxygen make that bare-wire,burn.
so glass-bulb make bare-wire glow long time without burning.
that is called incandescent-bulb,19th century technology.
source:'In addressing the question of who invented the incandescent lamp,
historians Robert Friedel and Paul Israel list 22 inventors of
incandescent lamps prior to Joseph Swan and Thomas Edison.[8] They conclude that Edison's version was able to outstrip the others because of a combination of three factors: an effective incandescent material, a higher vacuum than others were able to achieve (by use of the Sprengel pump) and a high resistance that made power distribution from a centralized source economically viable.
' in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb from 'Incandescent light bulb' in https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_light

0:37 halogen-bulb:has same tungsten-filament like incandescent-light-bulb.
but halogen-bulb contain halogen-gas.
halogen-gas catch stray-tungsten-atom which evaporate from tungsten-filament
then put stray-tungsten-atom back to tungsten-filament,to prolong life of
tungsten-filament and keep bulb-interior clean and clear.
0:59 fluorescent-bulb is a bulb/tube contain mercury-gas,contain electrode on both ends.
electric-current flow from electrode 1 to electrode 2 then electron
inside electric-current collide against mercury-atom in mercury-gas.
that collision make mercury-atom excited then emit visible-light and
ultraviolet-light.
white-coat on bulb-interior absorb ultraviolet-light then convert that
ultraviolet-light to visible-light(fluorescence process).
that white-coat prevent ultraviolet-light which causes cancer.
tanning-bulb has different coat.
1:35 sodium,mercury,metal-halide-vapor lamp,are often for lighting street,
warehouse,gymnasium.
sodium,mercury,metal-halide-vapor lamp,is a bulb contain gas,contain
2 electrode on both ends.
gas emit visible-light so sodium,mercury,metal-halide-vapor-bulb does not
need fluorescent-coat
1:51 led-lamp is just a tiny-crystal-semiconductor-gallium.
semiconductor has 2 layer.layer 1 give energy to excited-electron.
layer 2 give place for electron to relax.
electri-current transport electron from excited-place to relax-place.
excited-electron release energy in relax-place,that energy becomes light.
that is light-emitting-diode/(led)

Actually, white-light LEDs are in fact somewhat similar to fluorescent tubes in that the LED itself actually emits fairly monochromatic UV light, which is then converted to broadband white light through the use of phosphor coatings. Sure, the way the source UV light is produced is pretty different, but it wouldn't be entirely wrong to call white-light LEDs "fluorescent LEDs".

I tried the new CFL bulbs in my office and was pretty disappointed. While they didn't generate heat like standard bulbs the light emitted didn't last as long as a standard bulb IE the light produced became less after only a month or so to the point I was replacing the bulb with a new one. They're also very expensive and rules for disposing of them are unrealistic. In anticipation of the coming ban of standard bulbs, I've begun stockpiling them. They may produce heat, they may cost a few pennies more than CFLs to run but they LAST LONGER.
And, it is still the old-fashioned tungsten bulb that is best for art and photography. Modern fluorescent bulbs have an uneven spectrum and distort colour perception badly.

it just makes me sad that since incandescent lighting has been so dominant for so long that light bulbs are measured in Watts and not lumens. @kitvatae The convention for current flow is in the opposite direction to which electrons flow. This is because they didnt know what was moving, so they had a guess. Electrons come out of the negative terminal of a battery and flow into the poaitive. In most case this makes no difference to the analysis - except when talkind semi-conductors, where you have to use actual electron movement to understand the device. Hope this helps.

The HID lamps are the most interesting one. The movie theatres that still use 35 mm film have  large Xenon arc lamps in each projector that sucks up massive amounts of current while running.  Pretty neat to see one light up and warm to full power.

At 1:39 you included a picture of the airplane hangar at Hill Air Force Base. The lamps pictured are not arc lamps as you were showing just before. They actually use the very rare sulfur lamp. There are no electrodes in sulfur lamps because of how corrosive sulfur is. In fact, if you go to the sulfur lamp wikipedia page, the same image of Hill Air Force Base is included in the article.
